subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] On a keyboard
msgSnippet: ... What s the Model M? ... There s a very interesting keyboard project known as Optimus (http://www.artlebedev.org/portfolio/optimus/) which would be released
messageBody:
amd64_hacker wrote:
> http://www.pckeyboard.com/Kustomizing.html - The site of Unicomp.
> They inherited the Model M, the classic PC keyboard, from IBM.

What's the Model M?

> They're a bit costly but they last forever.
> They want 'certain volume requirements' for 'unique keyboards' though.
>
> Does anyone else know of any other custom keyboard manufacturers?

There's a very interesting keyboard project known as Optimus (http://www.artlebedev.org/portfolio/optimus/) which would be released in the end of 2006.

> What sort of layout should a QS keyboard have anyway?

Let's take a very wide text written in QS and estimate the frequency of each character. After that it would be relatively easy to make a Dvorak QS keyboard for English.

>
> tim_rice09 wrote:
> >
> > The keyboard that we use now was designed for a 26 letter alphabet
> > and the current way to write Quickscript uses the shift keys about as
> > much as the spacebar.

On my keyboard there are 48 alphanumeric keys. On yours, perhaps 47. On Brazilian keyboards, 49.
Even 47 keys would be enough for Junior QS. For Senior QS a tool such as Keyman could be interesting.

> > Not to mention the backspace key takes a finger
> > contortionism to use.

The BS key? It's at the upper right corner of all keyboards I know of.

> > A possible answer to this, build a new keyboard that may not even
> > have to have a shift key.
> >
> >
